reviews.review: 震撼。 故事很复杂，可能需要从头再品一遍

"are you afraid of GOD, 书籍者?" "No, I am afraid of you"

여러모로 좋은 점 투성이인 게임이지만, 가장 인상적이었던 것을 둘 뽑자면 하나는 화면이고 둘은 엘리자베스일 겁니다.
보통 게임을 할 때 어두운 걸 싫어해서 화면을 기준보다 조금 밝게 하는데, 이 게임은 대부분의 진행이 밝은 곳에서 이루어질 거라 생각해 기준대로 맞춰놓고 플레이했습니다. 그 덕에 이 게임이 빛을 정말 잘 사용했다는 걸 여실히 알 수 있었습니다.
더불어 게임에서 스토리적으로 동행하는 NPC가 이렇게 마음에 든 적은 처음이었습니다. 적절하게 도움을 주고 받고, 전개를 위해 지나치게 수동적이지도 않고, 그렇다고 플레이를 크게 강제하지도 않고, 게임 속 사물과 상호작용하는 모습은 생생하게 느껴졌습니다.
좋은 게임이었습니다.

this games ending made me realize i may or may not be retarded

[h3]I'll give BioShock Infinite the one thing I can really give it: The game starts out strong. REALLY strong. [/h3]The atmosphere in Infinite is established very quickly and solidly with great visual storytelling, expressive characters and clear showcases of the disturbing morals and practices of the floating city of Columbia. One second you're stepping into a world that seems like paradise, next finding out how hellish it really is, then jumping off of a burning zeppelin onto a zipline while shooting soldiers with your pistol.
And then.....what happened to this game?

The shootouts become more and more mindless as Booker (the player-character) gets stronger and all the other enemies retain their same difficulty level. Even though I played on the hardest difficulty available on my first playthrough, the combat was pathetically easy except for a few huge difficulty spikes with certain boss fights. Every time you die, you respawn with the same number of enemies near you, except you also lose money so it's harder to purchase upgrades. The zipline mechanic gets old quickly, and the melee executions usable in combat are flashy and originally cool, but just get annoying after watching the same few animations over and over again. Also, Elizabeth, your companion for the majority of the game, ends up cowering behind boxes for 90% of the time while in combat.

I'll give Infinite some points for exploration. The world of Columbia is enthralling, and it's really fun looking around for little details hidden in this gigantic floating city. However, the design of the overall maps doesn't always feel practical, and upgrade stations and items often feel like they are scattered around randomly without a good way to find them. How does Infinite solve this problem if you can't find where to go to progress the story, though? The most bizarre mechanic I've seen in this game: YOU PRESS A BUTTON AND AN ARROW SHOWS UP ON THE GROUND TELLING YOU WHICH DIRECTION TO GO. Yes, really. Never mind having an actual map or minimap that shows where you've been, where you're going, locations of collectibles, etc. Just press a button and press on. I'm not sure why Infinite couldn't have implemented an actual map system like its two predecessors.

[h3]Now onto the biggest problem with Infinite: the storytelling.[/h3]
As with the atmosphere, Infinite's storytelling starts out very detailed and satisfying to experience. It sticks with the gameplay-focused method of storytelling that characterized BioShock 1 and 2, which is great (I hate sitting through cutscenes), and learning more of the story by having Elizabeth as a companion. However, partway through the game, the storytelling COMPLETELY goes out the window, and devolves into one of the most ridiculous plots I have ever seen in a game. I'll keep things vague here as to not spoil anything for those who haven't played Infinite, but trust me - you aren't missing much.

The game starts introducing time travel and alternate universes as a way to drag the characters out of seemingly impossible situations, making it possible for the characters to alter their world in a way where the stakes of the game don't really seem to matter. By the end, Elizabeth is literally explaining the tropes and similarities between Infinite and the first two BioShock games as a way to explain how alternate universes work. I don't want to say more than that for the sake of not spoiling the ending. Honestly, though, the ending feels like when I tried to write an essay about a book in school without reading the book. It's incoherent, unsatisfying, and feels unrelated to events of the game, not to mention it literally tries to compare itself directly to BioShock 1 and 2 (probably just so that players will lump it in with games with plots that actually make sense).

Anyone who has played BioShock 1 and 2 is probably expecting some big plot twist in Infinite, and there actually IS something different about Infinite's plot twist: It's embarassingly bad. Overall, I don't recommend this game, mainly because of its somewhat monotonous combat and drop-off in storytelling, but I have to acknowledge that there are elements in Infinite of genuinely interesting atmosphere that aren't seen in many other shooters. It's better than many of those other shooters, but compared to BioShock 1 and 2? It's weak.
4/10

直接沉默
妹子演讲然后影分身一头摁水里给我整的懵懵的
这游戏现在也不过时，简直就是艺术，处处为你着想的伊丽莎白，给你捡硬币，战斗过成功没子弹给你子弹，没能量给你药瓶补充能量，还有那可爱的脸庞，让我不禁想多看几眼，伊丽莎白YYDS，我的女神

心情复杂。刚进游戏的时候，我以为很简单，就像玩过的所有游戏一样，杀过去。见到伊丽莎白以后，我想着，我一定会带你去巴黎。随着经历的越来越多，连枪管都变得滚烫，见到了太多，一路杀过来，我的心理只有赶紧把伊丽莎白救出去，去哪里已经不重要了......直到最后，我浸没在河水中我才明白，我一直以为我在实现她的心愿，我在拯救她，保护她。其实都不是，原来我在实现我自己的夙愿，拯救我自己的灵魂，挽回我犯下的过错。“我寻找过我自己”

现在去玩第一部了，回到海底，去一切的起点。

全程跟着你的NPC，看着她就好像是个真人一样，好看的不得说，还会与环境和场景进行互动，又会唱歌又懂跳舞，简直就是你后宫中无所不能的老婆
我也相信，夜空中闪耀的并非仅是星辰。视线所及的天空后有一片云端的海，海上矗立着无数座灯塔，灯光与脚下升起的木桥，无数个时间之上的交汇像极了花园的分岔小径，指引孑孓无依的痛苦者推开救赎的门。
